The Joint Conflict Reduction Programme aims to address immediate conflict risks and contribute to long-term conflict resolution and peace building in the Protocol Areas.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Increased, strengthened and expanded number of and capacity of human resources for government lead actors in understanding basic conflict handling mechanisms 2. Technical criteria developed to determine flashpoint conflicts using objective data collection and analysis 3. Government structures and systems developed for government lead actors for workload management and coordination 4. Increase in number and expansion in capacity of recovery/development activities in project areas reflecting enhanced conflict sensitivity 5. Acquired conflict handling knowledge and skills are reflected in government lead actors’ design and approach to targeting flashpoint conflicts 6. Increase in numbers and diversification of key stakeholders engaged by government lead actors in support of peace processes 7. Increase in number of coordinated linkages/projects/activities between recovery interventions and peace-led government processes 8. Inclusion of conflict sensitive practices in outcomes of recovery projects linked to peace processes

comment.narrative: • Government lead actors have received limited/ no technical training in conflict handling. • Government lead actors have received limited/ no institutional development support. • Targeted flashpoint conflicts determined based on political (not technical) criteria • Low levels of internal and external coordination by government lead actors with key stakeholders. • Limited range of approaches utilized to analyze and address flashpoint conflicts by government lead actors. • Peace conferences carried out as ‘one-off’ events with insufficient preparation/follow-up • Low levels of engagement of women and youth and other key stakeholders in government-led peace processes • Peace agreements achieved with some degree of political pressure • Government-led peace processes lack coordinated support to address identified causes of conflict • Post-conflict community needs identified without technical review or prioritization • Post-conflict recovery projects not implemented in conflict sensitive manner • Critical resources and lessons learned regarding conflict handling / conflict sensitivity not shared among key stakeholders
1. Project Monitoring, Reporting and Evaluation activities implemented timely and with the required quality (Annual Workplan was for Jan-March 2016).
1. Project Final Report Produced and approved. Project end Evaluation Conduced, Evaluation Report produced with its Management Response Plan.

description.narrative: Indicators (updated in 2014) 1.1 Number of baseline surveys, evaluations and reviews conducted; 1.2 % of Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and (SPCU) State Project Coordination Unit staff confident doing their jobs disaggregated by gender and state. 1.3. Plan to sustain the scheme in place 2.1 Number of young qualified graduates selected, trained and deployed disaggregated by gender and state. 2.2 % of volunteers satisfied with relevance and quality of training provided and applying at the field. 2.3 % of deployed volunteers who successfully graduate and receive certificates (disaggregated by gender and state) 3.1 Number of community members trained and Percentage of community members who feel enabled by training disaggregated by type of training, state, age and gender 3.2 Number of start-up micro-grants awarded and number of small businesses successfully started via the micro-grants disaggregated by state, gender and age of the business owner. 3.3 Number of small businesses successfully progressing 6 months after the start-up, disaggregated by gender of the business owner and age. 3.4 Number of environmental campaigns and cleanup exercises organised. 4.1 Number of graduation ceremonies and job fairs organised disaggregated by state; 4.2 % of deployed Youth Volunteers who successfully graduated disaggregated by state and gender. 4.3 % of deployed youth Volunteers employed after 6 months of training and graduation disaggregated by gender and state.

comment.narrative: Baseline: Darfur Youth unemployment estimated = 40%

1.1) The Youth Volunteer Scheme is run independently by the three SPCUs and one PCU 1.2) 90% of PCU and SPCU staff feel they are capable of doing their job 1.3) A sustainability strategy for the Youth Volunteers scheme is developed and adopted. 2.1) 60 youth volunteers from Phase I trained on additional subjects and deployed for follow-up activities 2.2) At least 80% of candidates satisfied with relevance and quality of training provided 2.3) 150 new youth volunteers are trained and deployed 3.1) At least 200 community members gained sound knowledge on sustainable establishment of small business and 80 % of them submit own loan proposals 3.2) At least 135 start-up grants/loans awarded for projects (3 winners/ community: Total 45 communities) and at least 200 ASCA groups established 3.3) At least 10,000 community members trained on business and environmental topics and 85% feel the trainings was beneficial 4.1) At least 150 youth volunteers and 50 trained community youth attend the job fairs 4.2) 90 % of deployed volunteers successfully graduated and received certificates 4.3) 40% of 150 youth volunteers (self-) employed 12 months after their assignment

Targets achieved. 1.1 The structure of the volunteer scheme was reviewed where the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) has been abolished. The Project re-activated and established State Project Coordination Units (SPCUs) in El Fasher, Nyala, Geneina and Zalingei. UNDP plays the role of the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and each SPCU is treated as an independent implementing partner and directly link with UNDP. This has improved coordination, implementation and institutionalisation within each state. 1.2 UNDP team supported the capacity development of SPCUs through weekly coaching, mentoring, and on-the-job training as well as customised trainings. According to the end of year survey, 100 % of staff feel they are capable of doing their jobs as SPCU staff. 1.3 A sustainability strategy and plan for the full independence and institutionalisation of the scheme has been developed. The strategy is currently under review by state stakeholders for finalisation. The strategy is expected to be adopted after the final review by stakeholders. The plan has provided further guidance on the future institutional arrangements necessary to sustain the scheme. 2.1 59 (54%M/46%F) from phase (I) were selected and given refresher training and redeployed to 47 communities in 5 Darfur states. They conducted and completed their monitoring and follow-up activities at the community level in January 2016. 46 of the volunteers were Business Volunteers (M: 29, F: 17) and 13 whereas Environment Volunteers (M: 3; F: 10). 2.2 Training evaluation survey results indicate that 97.6% of trainees were satisfied with relevance and quality of the training provided and applied knowledge and skills at the field. 2.3 150 new (58%M/42%F) youth volunteers were selected and trained for 4 weeks and deployed to 45 target communities in five Darfur states where they successfully completed the nine-month. These include 90 Business volunteers (M: 53, F: 37) and 45 Environmental volunteers (M: 19, F: 26) 15 Senior v

1.1) Target on track. About 80% of target households reported increase in livelihood assets during the last 12 months. 1.2) Target on track. Four Village Savings and Loan Associations (VLSAs) have been reactivated and trained on basic management and book-keeping in Central Darfur representing 80% of the overall target. A total of 60 members (all women) have since started savings and meeting on regular basis. 1.3) Target on track. Fourteen value chain related producer groups were formed and currently functioning during the year with a total of 3,375 members of which (50% female). 1.4) Target on track. Field estimates of production levels indicate that annual incomes have increased by up to an average of 56% through improved production, increased quality and marketing channels 2.1) Target exceeded. In total, 12 different infrastructures were established/ rehabilitated developed during the reporting period. 2.2) Target achieved. During the year, a total of 12,000 community members (66% women) benefited from the infrastructure developed/rehabilitated 2.3) Target achieved. All the 12 community assets (100%) established/rehabilitated are linked to markets and value chains and this translates to 100% of the developed community assets. 2.4) Target achieved. A total of 540 people (52% women) were employed in temporary labour intensive schemes during the rehabilitation of 6 hand-pumps in Abudowai, Kuromandi, Kateila and Hajir village (Kubum locality). Some additional 300 people (63% female) were engaged on voluntary basis during the rehabilitation of the dam. 2.5) Target achieved. According to a perception survey conducted, 72% of the people in targeted areas have improved perceptions of social cohesion within the twelve months of the project. 3.1) Target achieved. Within the reporting period, eighteen (18) CBRMs were formed and are now functional in the target locations. Also, eleven (11) CBOs were established in North and central Darfur villages with a total of 2070 mem

description.narrative: Darfur Field Offices Operations project has been set up to complement the new Darfur Field Office Structure in El Fasher, Nyala and El Geneina to strengthen ER Operational and Coordination Capacity of UNDP and Partners
Strengthened ER operational and coordination capacity (including repositioning capacity) of UNDP and Partners.
seat of a first-order administrative division

- RRR Sector operating effectively and improved coordination of ER activities - Knowledge and skills of UNDP and partners on ER enhanced through technical expertise and training - ER priorities reflected consistently across different humanitarian sectors and a coherent plan for the Sudan HWP strategic objectives of resilience and durable solutions in place

comment.narrative: - ER-gap Sector established, named the Recovery, Return and Reintegration (RRR) Sector - Capacity UNDP to meet expectations as sector lead nationally and in Darfur needs to be strengthened - Cross-sectoral prioritization of ER remains weak and uneven within current Humanitarian Planning and Coordination

1.1 At least 5 sectors have ER priorities reflected in them 1.2 Strategy paper on ER, resilience and durable solutions developed for Sudan 1.3 Twelve RRR sector coordination meetings conducted in Khartoum and sector established in Darfur 1.4 Four UNDP dedicated staff for RRR recruited and UNDP’s capacity as sector lead strengthened

1.1 Target achieved. All sectors have some kind of ER priorities reflected in their sector response plan and 47% of all HRP interventions can be classified as early recovery or resilience building. 1.2 Target on track. Several documents have been developed and are currently under review including a Protracted Displaced Strategy to be mainstreamed under the HRP as well as national-owned Durable Solutions strategy for IDPs 1.3 Target achieved. 11 meetings have been conducted in Khartoum (one is pending for December) and the sector is established in 3 states in Darfur. At the Darfur level, some 6 meetings have been held to date 1.4 Target achieved. Three staff under the RRR plus one 50% staff have been deployed.

comment.narrative: This project is for the DCPSF TECHNICAL SECRETARIAT, which manages the MPTF on behalf of the STEERING COMMITTEE.

PARTNERSHIP MANAGEMENT -Quarterly Steering Committee Meeting -Quarterly Technical Committee Meeting -Peacebuilding working groups meet bi-monthly in 5 states -IP meetings quarterly -Ongoing coordination with peacebuilding actors in Darfur
CALL FOR PROPOSAL -Announcement and publicity for Call for Proposals -Project appraisal for Windows 1 and 2 -Approval by Steering Committee -Contracting of approved proposals
MONITORING AND EVALUATION -Ongoing monitoring visits -Quarterly submission of IP reports -Quarterly review of submitted IP reports -4W training
CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT -Do No Harm training (dependent on SC decisions regarding DCPSF role and process for capacity building) -Basic Peacebuilding Skills Training (dependent on SC decisions regarding DCPSF role and process for capacity building) -Ongoing operationalization of gender strategy.
KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT -2 perception surveys conducted -Conflict analysis updated -Phase II evaluation conducted.
REPORTING AND COMMUNICATION -3 newsletters produced and disseminated -Factsheet updated in parallel with reports -Brochure developed -DCPSF video produced -Q1 and Q3 reports produced and disseminated -Biannual report produced and disseminated -Annual report produced and disseminated -2 donor site visits conducted -Website updated on ongoing basis

PARTNERSHIP MANAGEMENT -Quarterly Steering Committee Meeting: Two meetings held in June and December. Additional meetings were not needed as funding envelope was not finalised until November. -Quarterly Technical Committee Meeting: Two meetings held in June and December, to precede the two Steering Committee meetings. -Peacebuilding working groups meet bi-monthly in 5 states: As of Q3, 15 PBWG meetings held. -IP meetings quarterly: 6 multi-partner meetings held as of December. -Ongoing coordination with peacebuilding actors in Darfur: Adhoc meetings occur between DCPSF-TS staff and stakeholders. In addition, external stakeholders participate in some of the PBWG meetings. CALL FOR PROPOSAL -Announcement and publicity for Call for Proposals: N/A. The Call for Proposals was not initiated during the calendar year, as the funding envelope was not finalised until November. -Project appraisal for Windows 1 and 2: N/A, see above. -Approval by Steering Committee: N/A, see above. -Contracting of approved proposals: N/A, see above.
MONITORING AND EVALUATION -Ongoing monitoring visits: As of 30 September, 15 monitoring visits conducted. -Quarterly submission of IP reports: IP reports submitted to the TS on a quarterly basis. -Quarterly review of submitted IP reports: IP reports reviewed -4W training
CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT -Do No Harm training (dependent on SC decisions regarding DCPSF role and process for capacity building): trainings are dependent on materials being developed by other UNDP projects, there were no activities planned for the reporting period. -Basic Peacebuilding Skills training (dependent on SC decisions regarding DCPSF role and process for capacity building): as above. -Ongoing operationalization of gender strategy: A national-staff gender officer was hired and on boarded in October to support this.
KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT -2 perception surveys conducted: 1 perception survey conducted. -Conflict analysis updated: Conflict analysis updated during November-Dece

title.narrative: Local Governance Develop. & Public Expenditure Mangement

description.narrative: Strengthen capacities for local governance and strategic planning to entrench decentralization and actualize devolution in Eastern Sudan

The progrm will strengthen the overall governance and public expenditure management systems at the State/local level in order to enhnace the State Governments’ capacity for resource planning and public service deliver
second-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance

1. Locality plans linked to the state Strategic Plan 2. The State budget linked to planning framework 3. State Macro-economic policy formulated 4. Enactment of state financial laws 5. Amendment to state Local Government laws to clarify fiscal roles between Federal, state and localities 6. State administrative, accounting and finance regulations established 7. Institutionalized budget policy analysis and management function 8. Planning office established 9. MoLG coordinates capacity development for localities 10. Roles for public planning and expenditure management clarified 11. Number of laws reviewed 12. Number of policies reviewed 13. Level of harmonisation in institutional mandates and functions 14. Regular rhythm of policy dialogue under the Forum; 15. Regular rhythm of engagement with donors; 16. implementation structures established 17. Key Staff Recruited 18. Implementation agreements secured 19. Programme financing secured

comment.narrative: 1. GFS classification has only been introduced in RSS 2. all the three states do not have an institutionalised budget policy function and the budgets are not guided by macro-economic analysis 3. revenue predictions are inadequate and unreliable (up to 60% shortfalls) severely affecting the predictability of budget implementation 4. None of the 3 state has the required laws and regulations for financial and procurement management 5. Gaps in fiscal relations between state and local government level leading to overlapping or confusing roles in revenue and expenditure management and accountability 6. Gaps in fiscal relations between state and federal government leading to confusing roles in fiscal policy management 7. Institutional roles for budget policy analysis and management are not clearly defined leading to overlap and gaps in implementation 8. there are no locality planning units in the states of Kassala and Gedaref while in RSS only 5 of the 10 localities have locality plans 9. in all the 3 states the public expenditure policy management function is lacking 10. organisational and financial management skills are low across the states leading to planning and budget formulation 11. lack of a coordinated legal, policy and institutional reform programme; lack of policy coordination mechanism; overlapping legal frameworks and institutional mandates; low public service out put 12. Eastern Sudan Forum has not worked as a forum in mobilising 3 states towards objectives of the ESPA 13. Programme implementation structures not established

1. 60 trainees (disaggregated by gender) to be trained on strategic planning issues 2. 3 Strategic plans to be produced (Kassala, Red Sea and South Kordofan) 3. best practices applied best practices to be applied 4. 2 training programmes in core local governance functions to be conducted 5. One legislative forums and 2 strategies to be reviewed 6. 120 staff (80 males and 40 female on planning) to be trained within the planning department in the state ministries of finance in the East and South Kordofan 7. State feasibility studies/ projects preparation

1. 335 TB management units supplied with TB drugs 2. 14,630 TB cases notified 3. 847 people previously treated TB patients receiving DST (bacteriologically positive cases only 4. 85% of all the bacteriologically confirmed TB cases successfully treated (completed and cured) 5. 80% of HIV-positive registered TB patients given anti-retroviral therapy during TB treatment 6. 175 people with drugs resistance TB (RR-TB and MDR-TB) put on second line treatment
HSS 1. Support improvement of financial management systems, procurement and supply chain management systems and improve functioning of health management information system.
2. Strengthening the supply chain to increase access to HIV, TB and malaria testing, treatment and care services to the people of Sudan.
3. Strengthening the national system by implementing the capacity development plan, in collaboration with FMOH.
4. Facilitating needed technical assistance to FMOH on health system strengthening activities

1. 335 TB management units (100% of all existing facilities providing TB treatment were supplied with TB drugs 2. 20,138 TB cases were notified, representing 75% of the annual target 3. 1788 people previously treated TB patients received DST, which is 120% of achievements . 4. 81% of all the bacteriologically confirmed TB cases were successfully treated, in that they completed treatment and were cured. 5. 98% of HIV-positive registered TB patients given anti-retroviral therapy during TB treatment 6. 151 people with drugs resistance TB (RR-TB and MDR-TB) were initiated on second line TB treatment
HSS
ALLY Financial Management software was procured and installed at DGIHP, CNCDCD, CPDD and Epilab to ensure stronger financial controls in the FMOH at both PR and SR level
Financial management SOPs to strengthen internal controls have been enhanced, including responsibilities, authorisation limits etc.
A document to guide FMOH and all entities involved in Global Fund Grant management, on how to avoid and manage conflict of Interest, was developed
A policy detailing the steps to acquire, utilise and operate, maintain, and dispose of assets was developed
Two workshops were conducted to orient FMOH staff on the audit requirements for Global Fund grants.
A national supply chain strategy for pharmaceuticals and health products has been prepared for FMOH in 2017 together with an implementation plan
National Quality Assurance Policy and implementation framework is planned to be completed in early 2018
With support from UNDP, there has been improvements in strengthened procedures; improve infrastructure; the development of an ME framework and providing training in these areas.
Conducted site-preparedness assessments of sites proposed for the installation of GeneXpert machines and X-ray machines at State Level

title.narrative: Accountability and Citizen Participation in Sudan

description.narrative: The purpose is to contribute to the alignment b/w the development interests of citizens and the political and economic priorities of the State, by enhancing the capacities of civil society, political parties, media and parliaments in the budget process.

title.narrative: Accountability and Citizens Annual Report _ JanDec 2013_Revised

description.narrative: The Citizens’ Participation and Accountability Project purpose is to contribute to the alignment between the development interests of citizens and the political and economic priorities of the State.
independent political entity
populated place
Anti corruption

1.1. # parliamentarians trained in what their role is and how to effectively implement it (disaggregated by gender) 1.2.# parliamentarians trained in budget procedures 1.3.% parliamentary committees technically trained in budget scrutiny for use of public funds and service delivery 1.4.#. of sectoral policy briefs produced by the parliamentary secretariat pre-budget finalization. 2.1. % of audit staff with technical training 2.2. % of national and sub-national expenditure audited annually 2.3. # of points of access to audit reports to public (online, print, audit office); 2.4. % of annual legislative review and scrutiny of external audit reports at locality, state and national level. 3.1. # parliamentarians trained in gender budgeting scrutinizing monitoring 3.2. # of National and State budgets undergoing an annual gender budgeting review by the Women’s Directorate 3.3. # of relevant NGOs endorsing gender responsiveness of national and state level budgets. 4.1. # of training workshops provided on strengthening the parties’ role in budget oversight 4.2. % of registered political parties including PEM and sector budget policy in their policy platforms. 5.1. # lobby groups / CSOs stating they can access voting records / debate information / parliamentary information 5.2. # relevant CSOs stating they were consulted in budget allocation (to an extent to which they are satisfied). 6.1. % of media houses accessing parliamentary records on budget debates and public service provision issues 6.2. %of journalists covering legislative debates on budget policy 6.3. Frequency of parliamentary briefings on public expenditure related matters.

comment.narrative: 1. 1128 parliamentarians trained in legislative coordination in a Federal System, transparent budgetary process, resources allocation, oversight role of the Parliament and law drafting. 2. No trainings were done to the NAC. 3. No gender budgeting tools 4.1. No training workshops were provided on strengthening the parties role in budget oversight 4.2. No registered political parties including PEM and sector budget policy in their policy platforms 5. TBD 6. Media coverage of budget planning and implementation is low.

1. 100,000 individuals from targeted population reached through community outreach with standardized HIV prevention interventions 2. 32,465 men who have sex with men reached with prevention programmes- package of services. 3. 13913 men who have sex with men that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 4. 37713 sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 5. 16163 sex workers that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 6. 6874 HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care or treatment settings 7. 38 health facilities providing ARVs supplied with drugs and reporting no stock-outs of essential drugs

1. 100,000 individuals from targeted population were reached through community outreach with standardized HIV prevention interventions 2. 46,784 men who have sex with men were reached with prevention programmes- package of services, representing 120% of the target. 3. 9752 men who have sex with men received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results. This represents 70% of the annual target 4. 61,018 sex workers were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services. This achievement far exceeded the target by 20% 5. 8012 sex workers received HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 6. 6150 HIV-positive patients were screened for TB in HIV care or treatment settings -about 90% of the target 7. All the 38 (100%) of health facilities were supplied with ARVs and reported no stock-outs of essential drugs

1. 3,092,403 Malaria cases receiving anti-malaria treatment 2. 8920 health care workers trained 3. 1,254,156 households in target areas that received IRS 4. 122,463 LL ITNs distributed to target risk groups -continuous distribution 5. 4,924,664 LL ITNs distributed to at risk population through mass campaign 6. 103 Localities throughout the country reporting no stock-out of anti malaria medicine

1. 1,155,136 Malaria cases were treated for malaria according to national and international guidelines. 2. 9046 (101% of the target) health care workers received training. 3. 1,389,034 households in target areas received IRS -110% of achievement 4. 118,594 LL ITNs were distributed to target risk groups – which is 97% of achievement 5. 5,277,451 LL ITNs were distributed to at risk population through mass campaign- which is 101% of the targets 6. All the 103 Localities (100%) throughout the country were regularly supplied with anti-malaria medicine and reported no stock out.

All the 103 Localities (100%) throughout the country were regularly supplied with anti-malaria medicine and reported no stock out.

comment.narrative: Multi-donor pooled fund contributes to community level peacebuilding in Darfur.

90 % of community members sampled stating that trust confidence is restored 85% of tribal/civil society leaders sampled agreeing to a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict Output 1: Effective community-level conflict resolution and prevention platforms in Darfur are in place (53) Number of community based resolution mechanisms (CBRM) functioning 70% of community members with access to CBRM 85% of community members stating satisfaction with CBRM 75 % of the number of cases submitted that are successfully addressed 75 % of community members stating an increase in the percentage of cases submitted and successfully addressed 80% of community members state a decrease in communal conflicts due to presence of CBRM 90% of CBRMs have some vulnerable group representatives
Output 2: Cooperation between communities enhanced through shared livelihood assets and income generating opportunities and activities 113 community initiatives that deliver collaborative livelihoods income generating opportunities (including joint labour, trading, community youth and women) 10 new/re-established markets that enable diverse communities to interact/cooperate (15 additional) 85% of community members stating an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities
Output 3: Cooperation between competing communities over access to natural resources and basic social services increased 66 community based management mechanisms for natural resource (disaggregated by activity: water, pasture, forest reserves, migration routes, minerals, etc) 6 migratory routes demarcated / cleared /rehabilitated through communal consensus 13 additional areas of restoration of communal pasture/ fodder/communal forests 75% of community members surveyed in February 2015 confirming communal consensus around restoration of migratory routes/pasture/fodder/communal forests 87 social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ newly built (disaggregate by type) - 52

NOTE: Perception survey based results are NOT AVAILABLE at the time of this report, because they rely on the perception survey which will take place in Q1 2017.
Results for all other targets are as of the Q3 Update, and are subject to update by the end of the year. title.narrative: Strengthening Capacity of Sudan National Human Rights Co

description.narrative: Sudan National Human Rights Commission is the country’s national human rights institution established to support the Commission in the development of its capacities to be in line with the Paris Principles.
SNHRC is the country’s national human rights institution established in 2012. The main objective is to support the SNHRC in the development of its capacities to be in line with the Paris Principles.
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

1 •SNHRC offices functioning and operational at the national and state levels; •15 SNHRC Commissioners functioning in line with Paris Principles and international human rights instruments •Number of SNHRC’s laws and policies aligned with International Norms and Standards;
2 •A strategic plan developed for promotion and protection of human rights across Sudan •% of ordinary Sudanese are aware of their human rights of the role of human rights commission in the protection and promotion of human rights •Number of human right cases transferred to the concerned institutions, .i.e. judiciary, police, etc. disaggregated by gender and backgrounds; 3 •Number of human rights research and analyses reports conducted. •Number of journalists with various media houses gained knowledge in various areas of human rights •Number of ordinary Sudanese reached out through human rights campaigns and aware of the existence of SNHRC; 4 •Number of SNHRC’s personnel trained on human rights norms and Paris Principles •Baseline survey on knowledge of monitoring techniques

comment.narrative:
1
• 0 (zero) organizational structure or secretariat exists for SNHRC. • 0 (zero) operational policies and policy documents exist for SNHRC that are in line with Paris Principles; • SNHRC Commissioners are less aware of human rights norms and standards
2 • No Capacity Assessment conducted for SNHRC • No SNHRC report on human rights situation in Sudan available • Limited awareness of the role of the SNHRC by the ordinary Sudanese
3 • No research and analyses reports conducted by SNHRC • No human rights awareness campaigns conducted by SNHRC
4 •Despite ratifying a number of international treaties, there is no national institution with activities that aim at promoting and protecting human rights across Sudan.
1. Develop and install the complaint management system. 2. Conduct training to the complaint management committee on how to use the automated system and respond to complains.

1. The complaint management system is developed, installed and maintained. 2. The management committee staff trained have trained to use the automated system, and to receive and respond to the violation complains from public.

title.narrative: Capacity Dev for Aid Mgt and Coordination Phase II

description.narrative: Capacity Development for Aid Management and Coordination (Phase II) in Sudan through Strengthening Aid Management and Aid Policy Coordination

title.narrative: Capacity Dev for Aid Mgt and

description.narrative: The project overall objective is to contribute to achieving aid effectiveness in Sudan through strengthening aid management and aid policy coordination
independent political entity

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative:
Indicators Output1: 1.Number of government staff members o responsible for aid coordination functions whose capacities have significantly been improved 2.Improvement in organizational performance in units of MoFNE responsible for aid coordination (the organizational performance will be monitored through a capacity review in 2014) Indicators Output2: 1. Percentage of programmes included in SAID for which regularly updated ME data is available 2. Percentage of projects included in SAID for which regularly updated ME data is available
Indicators Output3:
1. Change in levels and quality of coordination of aid policy between government concerned departments (will be monitored through conducting aid policy coordination studies) 2. Establishment of sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forum on aid policy and coordination

comment.narrative:
Baseline output1: 1. Following the government restructure in 2012, the government Directorates responsible for aid management and coordination have been organized according to new institutional and coordination set up in the government. 2. Capacities of government officials responsible for aid management and coordination needs to be further developed to manage aid coordination after government restructuring 3. No comprehensive capacity assessment has been carried out for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination. 4. No comprehensive capacity development plan has been developed and implemented for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination
Baseline Output2: 1. SAID project module has been completed successfully. 2. SAID Fund Expectation module has been completed. 3. SAID programme and aid effectiveness modules have not been completed 4. Aid ME and information systems are not integrated and harmonized
Baseline Output3:
1. Government aid policy coordination between relevant directorates of the MoFNE (budget, policies, aid management and coordination and development directorates) needs strengthening especially after the government restructuring 2. There are no sufficient aid dialogue and coordination structures including government and development partners 3. A draft Sudan Aid Strategy has been formulated

1.Capacities of 200 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination functions have significantly been improved Targets 2.1. 100% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning ME system 2.2. 100% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning ME system 2.3. SAID includes data on development loans 2.4. SAID available online 3.1. The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy developed and coordination established 5.1. Study on “Strategic directions for peace building and sustainable development Darfur” completed. 5.2. Study on “society Status report 2014 is completed. 5.3. Concept paper on “fore sighting study for Sudan 2014-2030” is completed.

Indicator 1.1:
The project organized 3 training workshops at ElSaha Hotel in Khartoum, from the period of 26th April to 5th May 2016. The 3 workshops were attended by 135 participants from 16 states and focal points from core and line ministries at the federal level.
135 participants has been trained on the following workshops:
• Strategic Planning for 3 days from 26th - 28th April 2016 • Negotiation, Communication and Assertiveness for 2 days from 30th April – 1st May 2016 • Project Design and Proposal Writing for 4 days from 2nd – 5th May 2016
120 participants has been trained on SAID and Monitoring and Evaluation Systems as follows:
• The project has organized SAID and Monitoring Evaluation System in in North Kordofan and included participants from North, West and South Kordofan state from 13th – 14th November 2016. It was attended by 30 participants. • The second workshop has been organized on SAID and Monitoring and Evaluation System in Gezeria State to include participants from Geziera, Blue Nile and Sennar states from 16th – 17th November. It was attended by 30 participants. • The third workshop was organized for line and core ministries at the federal level from 5th – 6th December 2016 at Kanon Hotel in Khartoum. It was attended by 38 participants. • The fourth workshop was organized in Khartoum for participants from international organizations (bi-lateral and multi-lateral) at the federal level. It was attended by 18 participants. • The fifth workshop was organized in Khartoum for participants from Darfur states from 20th – 21st December 2016. It was attended by 22 participants.
Indicator 2.1: • Currently Sudan Aid Information Data Base (SAID) is undergoing development, review and updating process to include the development projects that were funded from grants up to first quarter of 2016; beta version is uploaded to a temporary website URL said.triblem.com for testing by all stakeholders from the government and the development partners till t

1.1 150 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination and management trained in Aid Management and Coordination. 2.1. 100% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning ME system. 2.2. 100% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning ME system. 2.3. SAID includes interface with loan databases available in the government . 2.4. SAID available online . 3.1 The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partners and endorsed. 3.2. Terms of Reference and membership for the government/government, government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy developed and forums established .
4.1. Production of timely and high quality project biannual report in July 2016 and project annual report in January 2017. 4.2.Project board meeting will be organized in January 2016 and final project meeting will be organized in January 2017. 4.3.. project manager recruited .

• UNDP Sudan’s Capacity Development for Aid Management and Coordination Phase II supported the capacity development of Ministry of International and Cooperation ( MIC) units and officials, on aid management and coordination through capacity assessments and training programmes on strategic planning, communication, negotiation, project design and proposal writing. • The project supported the AMCU in its role of National Coordinator in the Global Partnership Second Monitoring Round 2015 – 2016. The outcome of this process has resulted in the publication of Sudan Monitoring Profile (October 2016) by the GPEDC (http://effectivecooperation.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Sudan_14-10.pdf). • CDAMC II supported the development of Sudan’s development aid online financial tracking database Sudan Aid Information Database (SAID) - http://said.mic.gov.sd which hosts aid data from 2005 to 2016. • This project calls for improved coordination among government, donors and multilateral aid organizations that would make development assistance more efficient and effective. Proliferation of donors in recent decades, and fragmentation of aid among an increasing number of ministries and projects, has increased calls for coordination. • This project also built on the lessons learned from of the Capacity Development for Aid Management and Coordination Project Phase I such as the need to strengthen harmonization between the aid ME system and the Sudan Aid Information Database (SAID). The project is also based on the need to have aid dialogue and coordination forums.

The overall objective of this project is to create rapid employment opportunities for unemployed unskilled and semi-skilled workers through labor intensive infrastructure development.

policy, planning and administration

description.narrative: 1. Number of managerial, administrative technical personnel whose capacity is developed 2. Labour based coordination unit is in place with clear action plan and ToR 3. comment.narrative: 1. Existing Poverty Unit at the MOHRDL 2. MOHRDL previous experience in Labour Intensive Programs

Two Outputs: - Labour-Based Coordination Unit established within MOLAR, functional and operational - Capacities of unskilled young workers developed
Number of Target Beneficiaries: 2,000 unemployed unskilled and semi-skilled youth labourers in Khartoum State

1. The filing system (manual and electronic) is now functional with efficient classification of targeted groups, update to date record of training batches, categorization of employment opportunities and regular monitoring and tracking record of the youth. Thus far, the system has actual Data entry of 3,404 files (1,238 on Waste Management,1,208 for Entrepreneurship and 958 for vocational training). The new application forms are under filtering and categorization process. 2. The seventh batch of Entrepreneurship Training has been completed, with overall graduates(1,208) 3. Graduates from Vocational Training by the end of 2016 was 549 (target was 800, the lists shared with the VTC was more than 958). 4.The waste management sector remains on hold as no more training were conducted in 2016, so the total trainees in this sector were as for 2015, 1,238). 4. The total accumulative number of youth trained by the Project so far is 2,995 (Waste management (1,238), Entrepreneurship (1,208) and Vocational training(549)).

3,200 (i.e an additional of 205 unskilled youth trained in entrepreneurship) 549 vocational training graduates got employment opportunities at vocational sectors At least 20 sets of IEC materials developed. Four (i.e One additional media campaign event conducted)

The overall achievement of the Labour intensive project in Sudan from its launching in 19 February 2014 up to 31 August 2017 are the following:
1. Output 1: Labour-based Coordination Unit (LBCU) within MOHRDL, established, functional and operational Indicators: • 5 staff had been assigned to fully filled the LBCU positions/ functions. • 4 staff went on Training • LBCU manual for procedure is in place Actions: • LBCU staff capacity in Project Management, Microsoft Excel fundamentals-Information Database for Labour Intensive Record Software, labour coordination process, English language, Manpower Information System and Communication have been developed. Evaluation: • Currently the unit is working with minimal staffing due to distribution of its team to another ministry units.
2. Output 2: Capacities for unskilled young workers developed through labour based and business development methods
Indicators • Number of Project Board meetings held • Number of consultation meetings held with stakeholders • Recruitment of all required staff on time, but during the project lifespan, the staffing witnessed high turnover. • Number of Risks and Issues. Logs and Lessons Learned updated on quarterly basis Actions: • Base line studies were conducted to assess the local market employment opportunities specially for road maintenance and waste management and to target the unskilled young workers. • Letter of agreements were signed between UNDP, Waste Management authority, Entrepreneurship facility, Vocational training center, Social Development foundation for distributing activities and perform the project objectives. Evaluation: • 1,238 of youth were trained on waste management • 1,208 were trained on Entrepreneurship and have open opportunity to access to micro-finance • 549 were trained on vocational training • Job Placement has been availed for the interested beneficiaries to work at waste management sector to secure jobs at the Saudi Medical factory (6) are currently emplo

description.narrative: ?1.Number of small-?holder rain-fed ?farmers and ?pastoralist ?households with ?access to MF or ?MF/WII products ? ? ?2.Domestic finance ?committed to the ?relevant institutions ?to monitor extreme ?weather and climate ?change

comment.narrative:
?1. MFIs/Insurance companies ?have limited capacity to provide ?tailored financial services for ?smallholder rain-fed farmers and ?pastoralists. Current products are ?too generalized and do not ?consider flexible payment cycles ?and reasonable compensation ?criteria. MFIs/Insurance ?companies have not found means ?to access the remote, rural areas ??(e.g., mobile units), organize the ?farmers/pastoralists nor mitigate ?their associated risks. As a result, it ?is common that ?farmers/pastoralists use informal ?lending services. ?BASELINE:93,500 with access to ?MF, 0 with access to MF/WII; ?
?2.Existing budget plans do not ?have sufficient funds to maintain ?and operate environmental ?monitoring infrastructure. ?BASELINE: Annual OM budgets ?for weather and climate ?monitoring institutions are ?approximately, MoWRE: USD ??223,000, RSA: USD 100,000 ?and SMA: 300,000.? ?1.Currently, weather and ?climate monitoring ?coverage in the target ?States is limited. Most ?equipment is manual and ?up to 40% of equipment ?is not-functional. A ?BASELINE of what is ?operational includes in ?the 6 target States ?includes the following:? Meteorological stations: ??28 manual, 32 automatic Hydrology equipment: 17 ?water level, 4 manual and ??1 automatic flow meters? Rain gauges:? ?98 manual?
?2.There are existing ?regional and community-?based EWS initiatives for ?food security, however, a ?national alert system ?concerned with extreme ?hydro-meteorological ?phenomena is lacking. ? There is also a limited ?understanding of ?technical weather/climate ?information jargon (e.g., ?alerts are not translated ?into all national dialects). ?There is also no ?formalized ?communication ?mechanism for alerts and ?weather/climate ?information. End-users ?cannot provide feedback ?to improve the ?communication process.? BASELINE ?% Women who receive ?EWS alerts? states: 5%? ?% Men who receive EWS ?alerts/CI in target states: ??10%?
?3. BASELINE Bulletins are currently ?produced seasonally and ?da

1.1 30% (186,900 USD) increase in domestic financing for equipment/product operation and maintenance across all institutions (SMA, RSA, MoWRE, ARC) and states 1.2. At least 1 adaptation technology adopted by rain-fed farmers and pastoralists in the target states with 1 of these technologies targeting women or youth (% Women who received EWS alerts/CI in target states: 8% % Men who receive EWS alerts/CI in target states: 15%; disaggregation by producer will be confirmed 1.3 Conduct a Mid term Evaluation for the project.

1.1 30% increase in the coverage for climate /weather monitoring in each of the 6 target state has been achieved during this reporting period. 1.2 Two adaptation technologies: One applies for the preparation of the enhanced seeds in four states, and one for the land preparation for sandy soils in North White Nile state. 1.3 A Mid term Evaluation for the project planned to take place in 2017.

Target 2017 1.1. about 1000 SRFP with access to MF/WII (Disaggregation TBC) 1.2. 10% (62,300 USD) increase in domestic financing for equipment/product operation and maintenance across all institutions (SMA, RSA, MoWRE, ARC) and states 1.3. 10% increase in population who have access to improved EWS/CI 6% Women who received EWS alerts/CI in target states: 4% Men who receive EWS alerts/CI in target states: 5%; disaggregation by producer will be confirmed 1.4 Development of at least 2 tailored bulletins 1.5 Mobile Advisory Messages (SMS) 1.6 At least one WII product piloted for 1000 farmers 1.7 At least 1 flexible MF product developed which are geared towards the needs of rain-fed farmers and pastoralists 1.8 Conduct the CRF project evaluation

Results 2017 1.1 30% increase in the coverage for climate /weather monitoring in each of the 6 target state has been achieved during this reporting period. 1.2 Development of WII products was based on farmer’s preference in six target states has been presented to the stakeholders, accordingly 24 WII products have been developed for the farmers and pastoral groups. Technical and legal approval of these products is under progress. 1.3 Two adaptation technologies: One applies for the preparation of the enhanced seeds in four states, and one for the land preparation for sandy soils in North White Nile state. 1.4 4 tailored bulletins (2 regular of the SMA and 2 by the CRFP). The SMA used to issue seasonal bulletin and daily forecast to be disseminated through SMA state offices, Media, and even personal contacts, this bulletin will be doubled through the CRFP and covered more audiences through the project’s state officers and community organizations 1.5 Contacts have been made with the national telecommunication authorities to establish institutional relationship with the CRFP and to officially link the project with the working telecommunication companies to provide customized SMA services to the project’s target communities with EWS, MF/MI and related information. 1.6 Weather Insurance Index (WII) products was approved by the legal oversight authorities. 1.7 This target is expected to be achieved loan testing and delivery to the target groups by 2018. 1.8 Mid-term Evaluation Conduct during October 2017.

title.narrative: Promoting Utility Scale Power Generation from Wind Energ

description.narrative: The project aims to help diversify Sudan's power sources and reduce its reliance on fossil fuels, particularly for future expansion and to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.

title.narrative: Promoting Utility Scale Power Generation from Wing Energy

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Promoting utility scale power generation from wind energy to diversify the power generation in Sudan
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The location is in the Northern State lies North-West of the Dongola City

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative: a) Number of environmental and social guidelines developed for implementing wind farms b) Extent to which RE policies and regulations are adopted and enforced. d) Number of individuals and organisations trained and capable of supporting activity in the Sudanese wind market. e) Number of educational tours conducted to wind farms in neighbouring countries f) Number of MW power generated from wind energy. g) Number of wind farms developed in Sudan.

comment.narrative: a) Renewable energy master plan b) Preliminary wind measurements have been carried out as well as some feasibility assessments based on those measurements. c) wind atlas based on extrapolation of world data with high probability of inaccuracy. d) Limited exchange of experiences with neighbouring countries with established wind farm like Egypt and Ethiopia. e) Number of MW power generated from wind energy. f) Number of wind farms developed in Sudan.

5. 151 people with drugs resistance TB (RR-TB and MDR-TB) were initiated on second line TB treatment

1. 335 TB management units (100% of all existing facilities providing TB treatment were supplied with TB drugs 2. 10,208 TB cases were notified, representing 75% of the annual target 3. 979 people previously treated TB patients received DST, which is 120% of achievements . 4. 82% of all the bacteriologically confirmed TB cases were successfully treated, in that they completed treatment and were cured. 5. 97% HIV-positive registered TB patients were given anti-retroviral therapy during TB treatment 6. 54 people with drugs resistance TB (RR-TB and MDR-TB) were initiated on second line TB treatment

description.narrative: In response to identified widespread HSS weaknesses the project presents a laudable and highly ambitious program of HSS reform
independent political entity
Health - policy, planning and administration

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative: 1. Improved project management financial management systems at the FMOH to effectively and efficiently manage GF projects 2. Increased capacity for procurement and supply chain management systems 3. Improved health management information system to produce quality and complete health data/information.

comment.narrative: Zero

HSS Support operationalization of procurement and supply chain management systems through
- support to CMS by contributing to the cost of storage of health commodities - Distribution of pharmaceutical and non- pharmaceutical products from the Central warehouse to localities - Provision of technical support for the implementation, monitoring and reporting of the supply chain strengthening Plan with CMS Plan

- support to CMS by contributing to the cost of storage of health commodities. (achieved, and in progress) - Distribution of pharmaceutical and non- pharamaceutical products from the Central warehouse to localities (achieved, and in progress) - Provision of technical support for the implementation, monitoring and reporting of the supply chain strengthening Plan with CMS Plan (achieved, and in progress)

HSS Support improvement of financial management systems, procurement and supply chain management systems and improve functioning of health management information system.
Strengthening the supply chain to increase access to HIV, TB and malaria testing, treatment and care services to the people of Sudan.
Strengthening the national system by implementing the capacity development plan, in collaboration with FMOH.
Facilitating needed technical assistance to FMOH on health system strengthening activities.

TALLY Financial Management software was procured and installed at DGIHP, CNCDCD, CPDD and Epilab to ensure stronger financial controls in the FMOH at both PR and SR level
Financial management SOPs to strengthen internal controls have been enhanced, including responsibilities, authorisation limits etc.
A document to guide FMOH and all entities involved in Global Fund Grant management, on how to avoid and manage conflict of Interest, was developed
A policy detailing the steps to acquire, utilise and operate, maintain, and dispose of assets was developed
Two workshops were conducted to orient FMOH staff on the audit requirements for Global Fund grants.
A national supply chain strategy for pharmaceuticals and health products has been prepared for FMOH in 2017 together with an implementation plan
National Quality Assurance Policy and implementation framework is planned to be completed in early 2018
With support from UNDP, there has been improvements in strengthened procedures; improve infrastructure; the development of an ME framework and providing training in these areas.
Conducted site-preparedness assessments of sites proposed for the installation of GeneXpert machines and X-ray machines at State Level
Staff members of the national core DHIS.2 team have been supported to attend international DHIS.2 Academies, organized by Oslo University (the mind behind DHIS.2) Capacities of the FMOH to manage HMIS/DHIS.2, including customization and training of States and localities has improved significantly
To reinforce the implementation of integrated HMIS, supported the revision and adoption of master list of national core indicators, including indicators for HIV/AIDS, TB and Malaria

comment.narrative: -Organize workshops in 9 localities of East Darfur State in coordination and full consultation with relevant state authorities to enable stakeholders to access information on land and understand their role in land administration

-Have organized series of inclusive workshops in 9 localities of East Darfur State in coordination and full consultation with relevant state authorities to enable stakeholders to access information on land and understand their role in land administration

• Organize workshops in 9 localities of East Darfur State in coordination and full consultation with relevant state authorities to enable stakeholders to access information on land and understand their role in land administration • Broadcasting awareness materials through mass-media. • Develop land rights awareness and sensitization awareness materials on communities’ role (women and men specifics) in land administration as well as women’s land rights administration through preparatory workshop through theatrical performances in 3 localities in South Darfur, 3 localities in West and 3 localities in Central Darfur state. The events were arrange with the project implementing partners in each state to assist in broadcasting awareness materials through mass-media. Also community leaders at localities and admin units as well as invitation of local radio and TV to participate and attend theatrical performance sessions • Develop agreements for databases and land information systems (LIS) with ministries of Urban planning, Agriculture, Animal Wealth and Legal Administration/ Judiciary in the 5 states of Darfur. • Draft agreement for Adjudication policy for land dispute resolution mechanism by training in Arbitration Assessment for return villages of Solo and Torolo of Central Darfur, while access denied for another two return villages at Murdif and Abgaradil due to insecurity situation

1.1- A well-structured, GDMA is established 1.2- Regional Microfinance providers Network is established 1-3- Unified reporting monitoring the performance standards is developed. 2.1- Apex management team and staff are trained. 2.2- 20 Microfinance Providers are trained 2.3- 5000 Microfinance clients are trained on business skills and TOTs 3.1- 10 Public awareness for 10,000 users on Microfinance financial and client services and products is enhanced. 3.2- Microfinance information hub is established . 4.1- 40 community based innovative proposals are supported.

1.1- An Apex is already in place with a Director. However, due to the dissolution of the DRA, there is need for clarity on the nature of the new structure of the commissions before the activities related to strengthening the Apex and the GDMA could begin. 1.2 Progress on track 25%of Regional Micro-finance providers Network is established 1.3 Progress on track 75% of Unified reporting monitoring the performance standards is developed 2.1 Progress on track 10%of Apex management team and staff are trained 2.2 Progress on track 10% of 20 Micro-finance Providers are trained 2.3 Progress on track 25% of 5000 Micro-finance clients are trained on business skills and TOTs. 3.1 Progress on track 80% of 10 Public awareness for 10,000 users on Micro-finance financial and client services and products is enhanced 3.2 Progress on track 20% of Micro-finance information hub is established 4.1 Progress on track 10% of 40 community based innovative proposals are supported.

1-1- Provide training and other capacity building activities to APEX staff 1-2- Select and engage implementing partners 2-1- Provide training and other capacity building activities to Microfinance Service Providers and Clients. 2-2- Select and engage implementing partners 3-1- Organize more awareness campaign activities; 3-2- Establishment of MF information hubs. 3-3- Select and engage implementing partners 4- Monitoring and reporting the project activities against the planned activities 

Up to the third quarter all targets' results are on track;
1-1 Training materials and modules for the training of 200 MFIs, agents, Community Based organizations, unions, mediators and Business Development Services Providers are being produced through Red-R. After the training manuals have been developed the training will start within the next quarter in November 2017. 1-2 six IP are selected and have already started implementation in the five Darfur states reaching a total of ten localities in the region. 2-1 91 groups with 1,480 individuals are selected and started training and other capacity building activities on MF service providing and clients. 3-1 Awareness raising on microfinance, savings, microcredit, lending and guarantees have started in three states ND, WD and ED reaching about 1,200 potential clients through open forums, rallies, community meetings and radio. So far 38 % of output target's is implemented.

description.narrative: Indicator 1.1: # of young school dropouts and out of school children trained on vocational skills Indicator 1.2: # of young school dropouts and out of school trained on entrepreneurial skills Indicator 2.1: # of young school dropouts and out of school (disaggregated by gender) benefited from business development support services

comment.narrative: Atlas Activity 1 – Output 1: Output 1; Employability and entrepreneurial skills development for young School drop-outs and out school are developed Baseline: To be established Atlas Activity 2 – Output 2: Youth sustainable employment opportunities enhanced through Business Development Service Centre Baseline: To be established
1.1) 2500 of young school dropouts and out of school trained on vocational entrepreneurial skills. 1.2) 2500 of young school dropouts and out of school trained on entrepreneurial skills

1.1 Progress: On Track. Follow-up/update meetings with the MoE and vocational training centres and schools conducted. Vocational training centres in the different states were identified and mapped. Labor market survey report acquired for Nyala, Elfashir and Eleneina. Registration for 2000 completed, 500 in each of South, East, West and Central. Data compilation and analyses done. Agreements were reached with the training centres in the five (5) Darfur States to provide counselling and vocational trainings for the target beneficiaries. Six (6) follow-up/update meetings with the Ministry of Education (MoE) and Vocational Training Centres (VTCs) and schools were conducted during the reporting period. 1.2 Progress: On Track. Advance steps taken; processes for enrolment of targets commenced. Contacts with the institutions to provide business development and entrepreneurial skills training have been established. The selection of implementing partners to provide the linkage with the existing vocational training institutes is in its final stages. 2.1: Progress On track. Business development service providers /centers were contacted, two (2) introductory meetings were held during which their capacities were assessed. Call for Proposal (CfP) was announced across all 5 states, and in response many humanitarian and development agencies submitted proposals for implementing the ALP project. The review of the proposals is currently on-going to engage implementing agencies.

1.1: 2500 young school dropouts and out of school children trained on vocational skills 1.2: 2500 young school dropouts and out of school trained on entrepreneurial skills 2.1: 2500 (40% female young school dropouts and out of school (disaggregated by gender) benefited from business development support services

1-1Within the reporting period, UNDP and partners conducted community mobilization sessions in 10 localities within the 5 states for the selection of trainees. Preparatory works such as recruitment of trainers, development of training materials, signing of MoUs, selection of vocational training centres and market surveys are in progress in, East, North, and Central and West Darfur states. -Within the reporting period, UNDP and partners conducted community mobilization sessions in 10 localities within the 5 states for the selection of trainees. Preparatory works such as recruitment of trainers, development of training materials, signing of MoUs, selection of vocational training centres and market surveys are in progress in, East, North, and Central and West Darfur states.
-In South Darfur, 100 females have completed their vocational training in food processing and handcrafts training and have received start-up kits. A graduation ceremony was organized for the presentation of certificates to the grandaunts.
-In West Darfur 180 (3% female) trainees have been selected and are ready to start their training 7 different technical and vocational disciplines within the coming week. Additional 70 trainees are being selected to pursue training in food processing. 1-2 The entrepreneurship component of the trainings have been integrated into the vocational training. Thus the 100 vocational trainees were also trained on entrepreneurship management.
2-1 The construction of 3 integrated Business Development Centres (BDC) is in progress at various stages in West, North and South Darfur States. In South Darfur State, the land and relevant documents have been received from State Government. In West Darfur, the foundation works of the building has been completed and progressing. In North Darfur, the land has now been secured and mobilization of materials on-going.

description.narrative:

Atlas Activity 2 - JP Output 5: Livelihoods and income-generation activities are promoted in return areas - FaST 6.8 Pillar II. 5.1) 70% of households whose livelihood assets have increased in two years from project inception (e.g. livestock, agriculture production) 5.2) At least 70% of community assets rehabilitated or developed are linked with markets and value chains 5.3) At least 30% are women employed in temporary labor intensive schemes 5.4) At least one savings and loans associations formed and active (number of women and men participating) 5.5) At least two (2) producers groups established per village 5.6) livelihoods and income generating activities needs are incorporated in the assessment as well as the VRRC Returns Strategy
Atlas Activity 3 - JP Output 6: Capacity building for the Government of Sudan in Return, Reintegration and Urbanisation concerns in all 5 states (FaST 6.10 Pillar II) 6.1) At least 80% of the DRA/VRRC staff feel better capacitated and able to perform their duties 6.2) At least 50% of RRR Sector members report that sector meetings have been very useful in helping partners to discuss needs, gaps and priorities 6.3) UNDP has established RRR in all relevant states of Darfur 6.4) Relevant and active RRR sector members have increased with at least 10 6.5) One DRA/VRRC Returns Strategy developed 6.6) One information management syste

1.1) Progress – on track. Construction of 2 police posts in central Darfur underway scheduled to be completed by end of January 2017. Construction of 1 police post in Kornoi locality in North Darfur completed. 1.2) Progress – on track. The target has already been exceeded. However, more training is foreseen targeting female police officers. Within the year, 291 police officers have been trained to date. 1.3) Progress – on track. Out of 291 policers trained, only 30 of them are female representing 10.3% of the total. The reason is that government post female police mainly to the urban areas due to the challenges of insecurity in the rural areas. Since these trainings took place in the rural areas, there are not many female police officers. Therefore those trained represent 100% of those available. 1.4) Progress – on track. This is delayed and efforts are being made to get stakeholders to actively record and document these incidents. 1.5) Progress – on track. Discussions held with GoS counterparts to ensure that a few centers are established and activated during the forthcoming reporting period, Equipment and materials for CPV already procured and delivered to the field. 1.6) Progress – on track. This activity has been delayed and planned to start early 2016. UNDP rule of law team has held meetings with the UNAMID on the plans to kick start. 1.7) Progress – on track. Preliminary discussions were held with UNAMID in El Fasher and also in Zalingei. The UNAMID Police team has made contacts with the UXO team in El Fasher and detailed discussions are envisaged in next quarter. No security and UXO assessments have been made under the auspices of this project. 1.8) Progress – Delayed. Advocacy efforts are on-going to ensure return concerns are captured in relevant policies and strategies. However, the development of the Return and Durable Solutions Strategies are yet to materialize.

No office existing outside of Khartoum 4. 300 representatives of the judiciary, prosecutors, police and prison staff and social workers trained in human rights and 47 social workers 5. 82 parliamentarians and legal advisors trained on importance of law reform for child law and women’s law 6. UNDP and UNAMID teams in place with required capacities to support implementation 8. comment.narrative: Since 2014, Sudan has witnessed an upsurge in conflict-induced displacement. In order to address the needs of these newly displaced people, as well as those people who have been displaced for a number of years, the protection sector has identified a number of priority areas to guide interventions in 2015. These interventions will be carried out in collaboration with the Government of Sudan, relevant protection institutions and humanitarian organisations.

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative: This project has been established in line with UNDP’s role as Managing Agent of the Sudan Humanitarian Fund.

comment.narrative: Sudan hosts around 171,000 refugees and asylum seekers from a range of countries: Eritrea, Ethiopia, Chad, (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Somalia and Syria. Around 92,000 live in eastern Sudan, another 32,000 in Khartoum, and around 45,000 in Darfur. Sudan also has over 90,000 Sudanese in Darfur who were previously refugees in Chad, and have now returned to their country of origin, but not all to their area of origin. Finally, there are also potentially 350,000 individuals of South Sudanese origin (of which around 40,000 reside in Khartoum) who had been living in Sudan prior to secession that did not flee conflict. They have an unclear legal status and so are potentially at risk of statelessness.

• Organise 4 one day workshops ( seminar on SDGs). • Support formulation of the state’s strategies for development of statistics in the eighteen states of Sudan. • Support formulation of the sectoral strategies for development of statistics. - Central Bureau of Statistics to conduct meeting for the Resource Mobilizations for the Joint Programme for the development of statistics.

• 4 one day workshops ( seminar on SDGs) organized at states level - for the period between May – August, the training workshops were held in Gadarif White Nile , Blue Nile , Kartoum and Kassala states • The formulation of the state’s strategies for development of statistics in the eighteen states of Sudan has started and nine out of the eighteen states strategies have been completed. • The formulation of the sectoral strategies for development of statistics for thirty two federal ministries and three federal government institutions has begun; eighteen out of these strategies have been completed and implementation on five of these strategies has begun - The Central Bureau of Statistics has continued the preparations for the Resource Mobilization meeting for the Joint Programme for the development of statistics. The CBS organized a number of preparatory meetings with the NPC, MIC and the National Council for Strategic Planning in this regard

capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The project is national and intends to produce regulatory framework for marketing more efficient electrical appliances and setting minimum electricity performance standards (MEPS)

description.narrative: Health - policy, planning and administration

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative: project document prepared

comment.narrative: Various ad-hoc efforts are being made by different government entities such as the Ministry of Water Resources, Electricity and Irrigation, which has an initiative to replace one million Incandescent Lamps (ICLs 60-100W) with high-quality, long life (10,000 hours) energy efficient Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFL). In line with electricity efficiency efforts, the Sudanese Standards and Meteorology Organization (SSMO) is establishing a laboratory for testing performance of all electrical appliances. Different electrical appliance performance testing equipment have been procured and are expected to be installed by December 2015. The Electricity Regulatory Authority is also keen on developing new regulatory measures for EE; at present the country has no MEPS for any appliances or equipment. Moreover the Arab Regional Center for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency (RCREEE) initiated a series of workshops targeting public utilities, companies, universities and other stakeholders on developing the capacities for promoting energy efficiency actions.

description.narrative: 1. # of least advantaged young community members- disaggregated by type and gender- trained in entrepreneurial and vocational skills 2. # of least advantaged young community members- disaggregated by type and gender- temporarily employed 3. # of community based business groups formed disaggregated by gender 4. # of community based business groups enrolled into saving and credit schemes 5. # of top community based business groups received start-up micro-grants 6. # of community members business groups supported through Business Support Services in the 3 states 7. # of community members business groups benefited from additional finance and access to market

comment.narrative: Zero

1. 3000 least advantaged young community members in 3 states (between 500 to 1000 youth in each state) are trained on different vocational and entrepreneurial skills 2. 3000 least advantaged young community members in 3 states (between 500 to 1000 youth in each state) temporarily employed 3. At least 30 community based business groups (5 to 10 in each state) formed 4. At least 30 community based business groups received enrolled into saving and credit schemes through Autonomous Saving and Credit Association 5. At least top 30 community based business groups received start-up micro-grants 6. 30 of community members business groups supported through Business Support Services in the 3 states 7. 20 of community members business groups benefited from additional

Q2 (July – September 2016) 1- A total number of 1,914 of the beneficiaries in the three States have started their vocational trainings mainly in the areas of auto mechanics, auto and general electricity, plumbing, driving, food processing, handicrafts, henna tattooing and tailoring. 2- A total number of 1,358 beneficiary in the three states have engaged in temporary labour in 5 sectors: water networking, unskilled support technicians, self-income generating activities, heavy machinery driving, heavy machinery control and apprentices in small workshops. 3- A number of 480 in Red Sea State have been formed into groups and enrolled into saving scheme through their bank accounts, and groups’ formation has actively started in Kassala and Gadaref states. 4- A number of 358 beneficiaries in Kassala (241) and Gedarif States (117) are engaged in self-generating income activities like producing biscuits, cookies, other bakery or handicraft products and started saving up to SDG 2,000 in less than two weeks.

1. 3000 least advantaged young community members in 3 states (between 500 to 1000 youth in each state) are trained on different vocational and entrepreneurial skills 2. 3000 least advantaged young community members in 3 states (between 500 to 1000 youth in each state) temporarily employed 3. At least 30 community based business groups (5 to 10 in each state) formed 4. At least 30 community based business groups received enrolled into saving and credit schemes through Autonomous Saving and Credit Association 5. At least top 30 community based business groups received start-up micro-grants 6. 30 of community members business groups supported through Business Support Services in the 3 states 7. 20 of community members business groups benefited from additional

• 2,818 of least advantaged young community members- dis-aggregated trained in vocational skills • 1,358 of least advantaged young community members-engaged in temporarily employed • A number of 80 community based business groups have been formed, of which 48 from women and 32 from men. • A number of 2,627 beneficiaries have enrolled into saving and credit schemes. • A number of 55 community business groups organized as self-helping groups and composed of 1,446 beneficiaries in Kassala and Gedarif States have received a micro-grant to be redistributed as a revolving fund for start-up a business project. • 56 individual or community business projects accounting for 361 beneficiaries in Red Sea State have received start-up micro-grants through a Business Idea Competition. • 300 youth received training on marketing and establishment skills • 740 youth received training on Financial Education training • 640 youth received training on business advisory and counselling courses • 1446 youth received training on Microfinance concepts and the importance of micro insurance in small businesses. • 30 workshops, to enlighten the young groups about the micro finance institutions in Eastern Sudan their conditions, policies and criteria to approach, 236 young people participated in the workshops. • 17 learning visits to, financial institutions , successful youth projects in Port Sudan, Kassalla and Gararef, total of 500 young people participated from different groups
